Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research in Biophotonics: Towards high-resolution, label-free molecular imaging in deep tissue via stimulated Raman excitation and ultrasound detection

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1066776/1066562
Zhang/Yakovlev

The grand challenge of optical tissue imaging is the ability to penetrate deeply into tissue while preserving molecular specificity and high spatial resolution. The proposed project tackles this grand challenge by developing a novel imaging modality based on stimulated Raman excitation and detection of the nonlinearly induced photoacoustic waves. Referred to as stimulated Raman photoacoustic microscopy, the proposed modality combines chemical specificity through the molecularly selective stimulated Raman excitation with the deep penetration and high-resolution photoacoustic imaging. Compared with existing spontaneous and nonlinear Raman microscopic imaging, the maximum imaging depth is expected to be extended by at least one order of magnitude. Compared with existing photoacoustic imaging, the much needed molecular specificity is achieved without resorting to extrinsic molecular labeling.

This project will extend the existing knowledge on how advanced spectroscopic tools can be successfully used for biomedical imaging. It lays the foundation to develop a stand-alone molecular imaging microscope, capable of providing high-resolution deep tissue imaging without external labels. In the proposed research, the mechanism of the photoacoustic generation under the stimulated Raman excitation will be investigated. The investigations focus on how the elastic scattering in tissue will affect the proposed imaging modality. Monte Carlo simulations will model the effect of dual wavelength, short-pulse light propagation in scattering medium. These results will direct the design of the optimal optical illumination geometry in the future prototyping of the proposed microscope. Quantitative experimental studies will be carried out following the guidance of the theoretical estimation and Monte Carlo simulation. The sensitivity of the photoacoustic detection will be improved by matching the signal bandwidth and employing novel ultrasonic detectors. In non-scattering media, the sensitivity of stimulated Raman photoacoustic detection will be experimentally quantified in the presence of background linear optical absorption, whose effect will be mitigated by wavelength and/or time-delay modulation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The initial goal of this project was to investigate nonlinear optical absorption induced photoacoustic wave in tissue and, then, to develop a label-free molecular imaging technology by combining stimulated Raman excitation and photoacoustic detection. To achieve this goal, the first challenge was that optical absorption by stimulated Raman excitation in tissue was too weak for traditional ultrasonic detector to pick up any signal. The possible solution was to either generate stronger signals or to greatly improve the ultrasonic detection sensitivity. We tackled this challenge from both directions. To improve the single strength, we took advantage of the well-studied two-photon absorption in florescence dyes. To improve ultrasonic detection sensitivity, we worked with collaborators and developed a new type of optically-transparent ultrasonic detector based on optical interference within specially designed polymer waveguides (see Figure 1 for more details of the micro-ring resonator). Two patents were submitted and the new ultrasonic detector work received new NSF funding for further development.

While we were working on two-photon photoacoustic imaging, we asked ourselves that whether we can improve the spatial resolution of nonlinear optical imaging while still reaching a large penetration depth. Our tried to combine structural illumination with two-photon microscopy and later demonstrated ~100 nm spatial resolution at a depth hundreds of micrometers from the surface. This new super-resolution two-photon microscopy may greatly improve the current brain studies through imaging unresolved features and functions at greater depth as shown in the Figure 2. This deep-tissue super-resolution technology received an US patent in 2016. In 2015, we received a new research grant from a private foundation to further push this new imaging technology to neuroscience.

Along the originally plan to develop label-free microscopic imaging, and found out that the single to noise ratio using stimulated Raman excitation and ultrasonic detection was low, we started to explore whether we can still take advantage of the low signal amplitude and low probability emission nature for super-resolution imaging. We tested the hypothesis using nanomanufactured samples and obtained super-resolution images (see Figure 3). Later on, we further tested this method in biological samples and was able to image large biomolecules at a spatial resolution of 4-6 nm without the need for fluorescence labeling. The exact mechanism of the signal origin that enabled our label-free super-resolution imaging is still under investigation; but the observations have been verified by multiple lab members from several different molecules. Uncovering the underlying mechanism of the newly observed phenomena will be our focus of this work in the near future.

In conclusion, this project started from a goal that was later shown to be not optimal. During the development process, we gradually modified the experimental methods and developed three different methods, which all later became independent and impactful.
